comments.commentBody:
I am an alumna of Friends Seminary, and thank many of the thoughtful commenters above for their reflections on what a Friends education means.
(To those who would judge a woman who attended Friends in the '40s-'50s for not being aware of the specific tuition costs for herself or her children . . . um. Okay.)

The following quote sums up the struggle of trying to live the values of this school where I was (quite literally) raised (Thank you, Friends, for being there!):

"We've forgotten that a rich life consists fundamentally of serving others, trying to leave the world a little better than you found it. We need the courage to question the powers that be, the courage to be impatient with evil and patient with people, the courage to fight for social justice. In many instances we will be stepping out on nothing, and just hoping to land on something. But that's the struggle. To live is to wrestle with despair, yet never allow despair to have the last word." —Cornel West

I hope we're far along the pendulum swing. And that as a society we will begin to move toward support of a robust middle class - rather than elite schools with base tuitions designed subsidize the have-nots (which is, by the way, *everyone else*!).

That said, my non-Quaker protestant church recently reorganized to create a corporation to transact its business (and protect certain assets from risk); so perhaps the impetus for the story is something of a tempest in a teapot. (The coop preschool my kids attended a few years ago -- for $200 per month -- often had lower profile versions of this "discussion" with the governing body of the Unitarian church where we shared space.) Roommates and spouses know of these problems, too!

Good luck, Friends, we are holding you in the light.

I understand doctors of all ages wanting more personal time. I work in the operating room and I know how hard most of these surgeons work. I assist during surgery and I know that at the end of the day, I am not physically tired, but mentally, I am beat! It is as if my brain is going to sleep after I leave work. I cannot imagine what it is like for the docs. However, I do not feel one bit sorry for them. Just like every other profession, they knew the hazzards of the job! They are treated like kings and queens. Sales reps fall all over them. They  whine and cry at the slightest inconvenience. I am pleased that many of the docs are beginning to lessen their burdens....because that lessens my burden in the operating room. As for having children and feeling bad about not be able to be around them 24/7. Welcome to the real world. You chose to have kids and have a profession. If your profession does not work for your parenting style...change professions. I am sick and tired of parents whining and using their children as an excuse to not come to work or leave early. Maybe Monday I'll call in? My dog is looking peaked!

as a thirty year practicing physician in originally internal medicine and then emergency medicine, the elephant in the room that wasn't mentioned by this reporter was compensation. Dr Dewer III had to spend far far more on her education because of the rapid tuition inflation over the past 30 years,  and physicians reimbursement has been steadily declining for over a  decade...physicians are finally saying "basta" - but the public should not be lulled into thinking this is "better care", it is different and the jury is still out. One final point, the public should be grateful there are any doctors who will see them in primary practice when they can earn far more on an hourly basis as a teacher with 3 years experience in scarsdale public schools (and not to mention 7 years less education and lost sleep)

This is the happy result when women enter the work force: more pressure to provide humane working conditions.  Females now make up the majority of medical students in the US.  It is unfathomable to us to have to sacrifice our 20s in college, med school and residency only to emerge a slave again to insane work hours, demanding patients and astronomical debt at a time when the biological clock is ticking quite loudly. Like the subject of this article, I have also chosen a career in emergency medicine for a number of reasons, not least of which is lifestyle considerations. Now, if we could only get the residency governing bodies to realize that the 80 hour work week cap is still insane...

Now, if we could only get the residency governing bodies to realize that the 80 hour work week cap is still insane...

Young Dr. DeWar has found the way to not have to look the patient in the eye and say she'll be there. She won't.
Old Dr.DeWar is like that whole generation of physicians who are almost all gone -- who worked tremendous hours, with few miracle drugs, but never hesitated to sacrifice anything and everything for the good of their community. Just because all these young physicians as a group want shorter hours and more pay, their rationalizations won't make them anything but selfish imitations of real physicians.

Maybe this will humanize them. My surgeon is so singlemindedly focused he can barely carry on a civilized conversation. And any question not entirely about his specialty is met with a blank stare. I think the hours during medical training should be reduced also and a balanced wholistic and humanistic physician would be born.

"For doctors, the changes mean more control of their personal lives but less of their professional ones; for patients, care that is less personal but, as studies have shown, more proficient."

Yes, much more proficient in enriching insurance companies and other third parties.

I, as a patient, agree the doctors should have staggered hours, so they may get enough rest and may spend time with their families. But when I want to visit my P.C., I want to see my P.C. and not a Physician's Assistant, who is neither a doctor nor a head nurse.(How did they manage to create a niche for themselves with this pseudo title beats me?).

This is not entirely a good thing. The only way to give doctors a nice lifestyle is to have multiple doctors passing responsibility for a patient back and forth. It's difficult to explain, but when you are first year resident called to assess a critically ill patient at 2 am, you will understand why the new order that relies on frequent "signout" is bad for patient care.
I don't want a burnt out or sleep-deprived doctor. I want doctors who have lives and get enough sleep every night to function properly in the daytime.

No one forces a physician to stay in a lucrative position that is a respected career and in which they can grow personally and professionally.  If an individual who has chosen a medical career as a physician is unhappy with the number of hours s/he must work, I would suggest changing to a position where family time is valued, say as a greeter at a WalMart.

This is one of many sea changes in the practice of medicine. My son is starting med school and has no interest in private practice medicine. He is focusing on radiology, ER or hospitalist residencies in large part to avoid the mountainous paperwork of private practice and insurance claims.

Another factor alluded to in the article is the very large percentage of female physicians. They are less willing overall to forsake family time as their male predecessors were more likely to to. But this generation of male physicians has also had a significant change of heart vis a vis the extra hours.

I don't want a burnt out or sleep-deprived doctor. I want doctors who have lives and get enough sleep every night to function properly in the daytime.
Technological advancements and our crazy insurance system changed medicine to the point where it's hard to be all things for all people, and a team approach is superior.
